interaction_summary:
=== Purchase Information === Review Date: 2018/10/08 Average Rating: 4.0 Product Details: {'Content advisory': ['Foul language'], 'Audio languages': ['English'], 'Subtitles': ['English [CC]'], 'Directors': ['CJ Wallis'], 'Producers': ['Mallory Kennedy', 'CJ Wallis'], 'Starring': ['Ted Slauson', 'Bob Barker', 'Roger Dobkowitz']} Review Text: The guy who does the narrating (the principle subject) has this style that doesn't seem like he'd like any kind of game show at all. But it kind of grows on you. There is a surprising amount of footage that captures all of his appearances. I thought there would be a little more scandal to it. It really should be titled The Contestant Who Knew a Fair Amount. There were some tones of stalker in him, but that helped my fascination. And Holly didn't have to fear him because well, ya know, I mean- ya know? She knew.

Also, at the time when he was young, he was a good looking guy, I think that's how the models kind of liked him. In his prime, it wasn't weird to ask for a kiss from Holly. It was really sad to see Bob Barker get older, because you see the pics of him when he was younger, and you just couldn't look more alive. For even someone that good looking to get old, damn, what's that say for the rest of us.

But I highly recommend this doc for sure for sure watch it. Review Title: A really good documentary Rating: 5.0 --------------------------------------------------

It's a lively, poignant tale of friends trying to recapture their lost innocence in 1959 Baltimore.", ']]>'] {'Genre': 'Drama, Comedy', 'Format': 'Closed-captioned, Multiple Formats, Color, Letterboxed, NTSC, Subtitled, Widescreen', 'Contributor': 'Ellen Barkin, Steve Guttenberg, Mickey Rourke, Paul Reiser, Tim Daly, Barry Levinson, Jerry Weintraub, Mark Johnson, Kevin Bacon, Daniel SternEllen Barkin, Steve Guttenberg, Mickey Rourke, Paul Reiser, Tim Daly, Barry Levinson, Jerry Weintraub, Mark Johnson, Kevin Bacon, Daniel Stern See more', 'Initial release date': '2004-02-03', 'Language': 'English (Dolby Digital 2.0 Mono), French (Dolby Digital 2.0 Mono)', 'Aspect Ratio': '1.85:1', 'Is Discontinued By Manufacturer': 'No', 'MPAA rating': 'R (Restricted)', 'Product Dimensions': '0.45 x 5.61 x 7.54 inches; 2.08 Ounces', 'Item model number': 'MFR012569507722#VG', 'Director': 'Barry Levinson', 'Media Format': 'Closed-captioned, Multiple Formats, Color, Letterboxed, NTSC, Subtitled, Widescreen', 'Run time': '1 hour and 50 minutes', 'Release date': 'February 3, 2004', 'Actors': 'Steve Guttenberg, Daniel Stern, Mickey Rourke, Kevin Bacon, Tim Daly', 'Dubbed': 'French', 'Subtitles': 'English, French', 'Producers': 'Jerry Weintraub, Mark Johnson', 'Studio': 'Studio Distribution Services', 'Writers': 'Barry Levinson', 'Country of Origin': 'USA', 'Number of discs': '1'} I got this movie to watch with my mom because she grew up on the East Coast around this time. It's a sweet movie with a little R ish material, not too much, but all in all a nice escape, and a movie that stands up to rewatching. It's a sweet movie with a little R ish material {'Subtitles': ['None available'], 'Directors': ['Henry Singer'], 'Producers': ['Henry Singer'], 'Studio': ['XiveTV']} They should retitle this one "The Most Narcissistic Photographer in the History of Photographs". This guy tried to make the entire story about him, a guy who pushed a button on a machine. Line after line of how he was Picasso, how his photograph compared to Pulitzer Prize winning photos, every last thing the guy said was about himself. I defy you to find a sentence without the word "I" or "me" in it. The Most Narcissistic Photographer in the History of Photographs {'Content advisory': ['Violence', 'foul language'], 'Audio languages': ['English'], 'Subtitles': ['English [CC]'], 'Directors': ['Stephanie Kaim'], 'Producers': ['Irène Challand', 'Claire Colart', 'Sandrine Delegiewicz', 'Stéphane Haumant', 'Gaspard Lamunière', 'Daniel Leconte', 'Andreas Lemos', 'Émilie Raffoul', 'Olivier Stroh'], 'Studio': ['MagellanTV']} Out after 40 seconds. I at first couldn't realize if the video was warped, or the guy had a speech impediment. No way could I make it through 90 minutes of that. Out after 40 seconds. I at first couldn't realize ... {'Content advisory': ['Violence', 'frightening scenes', 'foul language'], 'Audio languages': ['English'], 'Subtitles': ['English [CC]'], 'Directors': ['None'], 'Starring': ['Ruth Blackwell'], 'Studio': ['Independent Documentary']} Water faucets running and junk scattered on the floor. That HAD to be a ghost! I now believe in ghosts! This was a lower budget Blair Witch Project that was hoping a large percentage of the people were too young to remember The Blair Witch Project. The only reason it barely made it to three stars is that it's a cute couple. And they did get me to watch the whole thing. This was very terrible. This was very terrible. {'Content advisory': ['Alcohol use', 'foul language', 'sexual content'], 'Audio languages': ['English'], 'Subtitles': ['English [CC]'], 'Directors': ['Lee Schloss'], 'Producers': ['Mike Bocchetti'], 'Starring': ['Mike Bocchetti', 'Artie Lange', 'Sal the Stockbroker']} The quality of the video could be better, but the quality of Mike could not. He's got a heart of gold, and if you want to see who he is, I recommend youtubing "Mike Bocchetti and the weather". Crisp video quality, and Mike never has a bad word to say about anyone. His true comic talents are brought out by Artie Lange on Artie's show when he does the weather. Please watch, I've seen it so many times. Mike is a 5 star person {'Content advisory': ['Foul language'], 'Audio languages': ['English'], 'Subtitles': ['English [CC]'], 'Directors': ['CJ Wallis'], 'Producers': ['Mallory Kennedy', 'CJ Wallis'], 'Starring': ['Ted Slauson', 'Bob Barker', 'Roger Dobkowitz']} The guy who does the narrating (the principle subject) has this style that doesn't seem like he'd like any kind of game show at all. But it kind of grows on you. There is a surprising amount of footage that captures all of his appearances. I thought there would be a little more scandal to it. It really should be titled The Contestant Who Knew a Fair Amount. There were some tones of stalker in him, but that helped my fascination. And Holly didn't have to fear him because well, ya know, I mean- ya know? She knew.

Also, at the time when he was young, he was a good looking guy, I think that's how the models kind of liked him. In his prime, it wasn't weird to ask for a kiss from Holly. It was really sad to see Bob Barker get older, because you see the pics of him when he was younger, and you just couldn't look more alive. For even someone that good looking to get old, damn, what's that say for the rest of us.

But I highly recommend this doc for sure for sure watch it. A really good documentary
profile:
**User Summary:**

The user has a pronounced preference for comedy films that blend drama and nostalgia, favoring narratives rich in personal connections and cultural experiences. Their refined taste highlights a passion for balanced storytelling and deep character exploration, with a distinct aversion to self-absorbed protagonists.

Recent interactions showcase an increasing intolerance for poorly executed filmmaking, underscoring a demand for emotional engagement and narrative clarity. This evolution is evident in their critical approach toward projects perceived as lacking coherence, despite recognizing redeeming qualities, such as captivating lead performances.

The user remains committed to nuanced storytelling, as evidenced by their engagement with multi-language audio and subtitles, reinforcing a preference for accessible narratives. Their feedback style emphasizes emotional impact and entertainment value, but they are now less forgiving of subpar content.

A recent interaction reflects their admiration for a documentary that features an authentic and charming narrator despite overall production shortcomings. This suggests an evolving perspective that values genuine contributions from individuals in the entertainment realm while maintaining high standards for quality.

Overall, this profile outlines a sophisticated viewer who prizes quality storytelling and character development. They seek films that offer warmth and nuanced explorations of complex themes, coupled with an increasingly stringent demand for coherence and execution in their cinematic experiences.
